results.title: Moral development (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Developmental psychology today”.
Examines two opposing theories of moral development, that of Lawrence Kohlberg who believes that there are stages of moral development tied to cognitive development, and that of the learning theorists who contend that moral behaviour like all behaviour is learned, and that reasons for actions are irrelevant. Using Dr Stanley Milgrim’s famous obedience experiment each of the six stages of moral reasoning is represented in this film, one at a time, by six different participants. The stages differ in the types of reasons a person gives for making a decision about a moral dilemma and in the type of concern the person shows for the self, society, and authority.

results.title: Infancy (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Glen Howard, Howard Gardner, Jerome Kagan, Harper & Row and Bay State Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Developmental psychology today”.
Examines behaviour and cognitive patterns characteristic of the first 18 months of life, including object permanence, stranger and separation anxiety, reaction to discrepancy and maturing co-ordinations. Discusses individual differences in infant temperament.

results.title: Cognitive development (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Peter Jordan and CRM Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Developmental psychology today”.
Describes and portrays two major theories of cognitive development: Jean Piaget’s developmental stage approach with its emphasis on environmental and maturational factors; and the cognitive, learning or behavioural approach of Jerome Bruner, Jerome Kagan and Sidney Bijou. Also examines Dr Siegfried Engelmann’s behaviorist view of intellectual development. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary/teacher levels.

Also examines Dr Siegfried Engelmann’s behaviorist view of intellectual development. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary/teacher levels.

results.title: Crystals and their structures
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown and Chemical Education Material Study Education Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Crystals have plane faces, sharp edges, sharp melting points, and may cleave easily to give new plane surfaces. They also interact with x-rays to produce well-defined diffraction patterns. Experiments are performed in a ripple tank on an unknown crystalline array so that the student sees the principles and measurements by which actual crystal structures are determined. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Chemical families
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Starting with a display of samples of over 70 elements, the film demonstrates methods by which chemical similarities among the elements have provided the basis for dividing them logically into families. By experiment and observation metals, non-metals, and the doubtful elements are grouped. The film demonstrates how atomic numbers have provided the key to the ordering of the elements in the periodic table.

results.title: Catalysis
results.creator_credit: Manufacturing Chemists' Association and CHEM Study
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Emphasises that catalysts are typical chemical reactants, being unique only in that catalysts are regenerated during the reaction. Demonstrates, using animation, and interprets three simple catalyzed reactions: the decomposition of formic acid, using sulphuric acid as catalyst; the reactions between hydrogen and oxygen, using pure platinum as catalyst; and the reaction between acidified benzidine and hydrogen peroxide using peroxidase in the human blood as a catalyst.

results.title: Bromine - Element from the sea
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Experiments show the great reactivity of bromine with metals and non-metals, giving products readily soluble in water. A procedure is developed for the extraction of bromine from a dilute sodium bromide solution such as sea water.

results.title: Vibration of molecules
results.creator_credit: Gerald Nevius and Sutherland Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study”
Explains the relationship between the structure of a molecule and its vibrational motions. Water, carbon dioxide, and methane are discussed in detail. The effect of molecular collision, or absorption of light, on molecular vibrations is illustrated.

results.title: The Hydrogen atom as viewed by quantum mechanics
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
The model for the electron probability distribution in the hydrogen atom is provided by quantum mechanics. Confidence in this model is justified because the calculated energies agree closely with the experimental energies obtained from the hydrogen atom spectrum. The probability distribution of the electron is demonstrated by analogies. Animation shows the outstanding features of the hydrogen atom.
results.title_for_label: The Hydrogen atom as viewed by quantum mechanics
results.creator_credit_for_label: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Davidson Films
results.description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
The model for the electron probability distribution in the hydrogen atom is provided by quantum mechanics. Confidence in this model is justified because the calculated energies agree closely with the experimental energies obtained from the hydrogen atom spectrum. The probability distribution of the electron is demonstrated by analogies. Animation shows the outstanding features of the hydrogen atom.

results.title: Vanadium: a transition element
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Eipsode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study”
Vanadium is studied as a typical transition element. The different oxidation states of vanadium and their colours are observed and then identified by means of a quantitative titration of vanadium(II) solution with cerium(IV) solution. The oxidation states and the observed colours are correlated with the electronic structures using an orbital board. The formation of complex ions containing vanadium in different oxidation states is demonstrated. The variations in properties in terms of ion size and charge density are discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions
